text: Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So you uh, we went through uh the you know clinical trial and you went to surgery, and uh when they did the surgery uh you had some lymph nodes uh that popped up, and we uh wanted to get a better sense of using the special PSMA scan, uh what was going on, where there was cancer left. And so we had to do the scan, and uh the good news is we found prostate cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, and uh the bad news is we found prostate cancer, but we sort of knew it was there. Patient: Right. Doctor: And and what we saw on the scan basically is in your pelvis here, from here down to where the prostate was there’s still a lot of lymph nodes with prostate cancer in them. The good news is we didn’t see any higher; so it sort of ends at the pelvis, and we didn’t see any in the bones. Patient: That is good news. Doctor: So. So from my standpoint that’s really great news. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um, because we knew there was cancer, and so now we know sort of about where it is. So the question is, is how do we proceed – Patient: Yes. Doctor: - uh to try and get rid of this. Um, and uh you know uh I certainly have no it’s easy for me to say; I have no regrets that you did that clinical trial.

text: Patient: Well. We would start first with the Xtandi. I have to – the disease has to progress some more – Doctor: Uh, by PSA only. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: I don’t think you’re gonna need new scans, but that maybe sort of something down the road, but I think you, you really just have to have a rising PSA on the enzalutamide, and then we have to repeat that ARV seven. It has to be positive on enzalutamide, and then you can go onto the study. (Pause) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So, we can follow up that you can afford it. If you want it, then you have to decide, “Okay, I’m gonna take it.” With the idea that you’re going towards this, and maybe about a thirteen percent chance that the PSA will drop just because we added back the Xtandi. Okay? Family Member: Is that Xtandi a, a injection or a pill or – Doctor: It’s a pill. He takes four pills a day. Family Member: Oh, alright. I get it. Doctor: Gives you fatigue, tiredness. Patient: I had two extra bottles I gave back to Family Member: And then, uh, and then he’s going to take it for awhile. And he’ll come down here and get -- in a month or how--how soon?

text: Patient: Can I go to England and get it? Doctor: Or one of those countries. I think Germany or England, yes, one of the European countries. Patient: I could go over there and do it. How long do they treat you, though, for that? Doctor: It’s about four doses, a total of four doses every six weeks or something. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So it’s not, uh, it’s not a one-time deal. Family Member: Wow. Patient: Yeah, I didn’t imagine, no idea. Doctor: Yeah. No. I agree. Yeah. So I think you should consider going on the study because that is our only chance, at least in the U.S., of getting on the medication. If you don’t, we are no better off than what we started with. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But now is a good time to consider the study because your cancer is not going crazy. Okay? Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? It’s only the PSA is inching up, but nothing else is getting worse.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So often we think of bone as being, we have this sort of feeling that bone is worse, but mostly because we just have trouble imaging and seeing how it changes. So, uh, but it also affects some of the trials we have because those trials require biopsies of tumor tissue, and it’s really hard to get tumor tissue from the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it may alter what we can do in terms of trials. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So today, I thought we could talk a little bit about kind of what the standard things are to do next, and then we could talk a little bit about some trials that we have. The typical thing we would do next is either to put you on another hormone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so you’d be on the shot and a pill. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, we talked before about there’s a drug called, Zytiga, and a drug called, Xtandi. Uh, they both could, could work very well, uh, and they’re both associated with improving survival in men who get the drugs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The main side effect of both is fatigue. Patient: Um hum.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
